author: rajah_matik
content: Hello everyone!  My name is Paul.  I’m a self taught developer from the Big Island of Hawaii.  Most of my dev work has been done in JavaScript (vanilla JS, Node.js, and React.js) and I’ve been diving into TypeScript recently.  I’ve learned a bit about computer science concepts on my own, and I’m happy to do a deep dive on whatever area of the Eth protocols that I can have the most impact.  I look forward to working with you all!  Aloha.

author: ttarsi
content: Hey everyone, I'm tyler. I was a machine learning engineer for a couple years, but couldn't resist building the cypherpunk future and I am currently building an mvp for a new defi product. I like python, c++, rust, and also play around with some functional languages for fun and (non)profit. I'm also a surfer. Cheers. Excited about the program and hope to meet some cool people

author: pipermerriam
content: Second session of office hours starting now in #lounge , feel free to drop in, lurk, ask questions

author: th4s_
content: Does dynamic state access mean, that you cannot predict from looking at the transaction data alone, which state will be modified? You have to run it through the EVM to know?

author: sky.cactus
content: It means the accessed state may differ depending on the state of the world (including things like timestamp, parent blockhash, other transactions included ahead of you, etc.).

author: th4s_
content: hmm thx, but I have a hard time making sense of it. I was referring to `dynamic state access` in this context: https://github.com/ethereum/stateless-ethereum-specs/wiki/Glossary#dynamic-state-access-dsa

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Yes, because your transaction can depend on external factors, you can't predict what is going to be executed from the transaction alone.
Consider the following transaction:
```
...
SLOAD
JUMPI
```
Which loads a slot from storage and depending on its value jumps. If now a transaction "swoops in" and sets the storage slot to something different, you can't predict which state will be modified by your program

author: th4s_
content: Then it is predictable if a transaction is dynamic/static by looking at the evm instructions it contains?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Yes, everything that has SLOAD, Timestamp,... opcodes is dynamic

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Would be cool to have a list of these opcodes

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Because static transactions can be parallelized

author: th4s_
content: Has there been any research on how intertwined the state is, meaning how much state (number of previous transactions) is needed to process a new transaction on average?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Not that I know of, but I would guess its a lot, e.g. contracts like uniswap heavily depend on the previous transactions

author: greg_vardy
content: Yeah I’ve been thinking about SIMD for PIC

author: lammatail223169
content: Wouldn't anything changing memory/the stack not depend on state? + maybe some utilities like the hash op codes? These should be grouped by prefix

author: lammatail223169
content: slightly out of date, but this is my go to link when I have OP code questions (beside the yellow paper) https://ethervm.io/#0B

author: lautaro.meiners4290
content: Hi everyone! I'm Lautaro a self-taught programmer from Buenos Aires, Argentina. Really hyped about this programme and the opportunity to to take a deep dive into one of the most interesting developments of the last couple of years, ethereum. Salud!
